posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Even the cheap “knock-offs” from AndyMark are insanely expensive. Aren’t there better lights for your application? You need a relay to power the RSL with Arduino control.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
The relay will act as the on and off switch for the RSL and can be triggered from a Digital Output line of the Arduino. That allows you to use two different power levels. The digital IO of an Arduino is limited and not meant to be like a power supply.

9V or 12V positive goes into the switching side of the relay. Another wire on the contacting leg of the relay is connected to your RSL . When the relay is off the device is not connected. Then when the Relay is triggered by the Arduino it will turn move the switch with small electro-magnets and the switch will connect. The RSL then turns on.

This means you have to connect a signal line and ground to the Arduino on the opposite side. Most breakout boards make it easy to see which side is which.

Like this. Ignore the text, I think it’s from an AliBaba listing. In the picture the 9v/12v and RSL positive would be connected on the large Load side of the rely breakout board. In this case you would want Normally Open (NO) and COM pins so it isn’t powered normally because the circuit is open. Then the signal side is connected back to your Arduino.

posts.cooked: Thank you this will be a great help.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: If you want to run a real RSL (which takes 12V), a part such as this one can provide 12V from a 5V supply and be turned on/off using a digital output from something like an arduino.
